_meta.source: 38 CFR 3.105(a), 38 CFR 20.1403, Russell v. Principi (3 Vet. App. 310, 313-14), Fugo v. Brown (6 Vet. App. 40)
_meta.authority: Code of Federal Regulations, Title 38; U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims

definition.text: Clear and Unmistakable Error is a very specific and rare kind of error. It is the kind of error, of fact or of law, that when called to the attention of later reviewers compels the conclusion, to which reasonable minds could not differ, that the result would have been manifestly different but for the error.
definition.certaintyStandard: If it is not absolutely clear that a different result would have ensued, the error complained of cannot be clear and unmistakable.

threePartTest.description: To establish CUE, all three elements must be proven:

elements.description: Either the correct facts, as they were known at the time, were not before the adjudicator, OR the statutory and regulatory provisions extant at the time were incorrectly applied.
The error must be undebatable — reasonable minds could not differ that an error occurred. It must compel the conclusion that an error was made.
Had the error not been made, the outcome of the decision would have been manifestly different. The error must be outcome-determinative.

whatConstituesCUE.type: Incorrect application of regulations or statutes
whatConstituesCUE.description: VA applied outdated rules, wrong diagnostic codes, or ignored relevant laws in making a rating decision.
examples: Applying the wrong diagnostic code to rate a condition
Failing to apply a regulation that was in effect at the time of the decision
Using superseded rating criteria instead of the criteria in effect

whatConstituesCUE.type: Overlooking evidence in the claims file
whatConstituesCUE.description: VA failed to consider or evaluate evidence that was part of the original claims file.
examples: Service treatment records showing in-service injury were in the file but not discussed
Medical evidence clearly supporting a higher rating was ignored
Buddy statements or lay evidence in the file were not considered

whatConstituesCUE.description: VA overlooked or misinterpreted key facts in the veteran's records.
examples: Incorrect service dates used in decision
Wrong medical condition addressed in rating
Incorrect characterization of the evidence of record

whatConstituesCUE.type: Failure to apply presumption of soundness
whatConstituesCUE.description: VA wrongly denied claim on basis condition was pre-existing without clear and convincing evidence of pre-existence.
examples: Entrance examination showed no defects but VA denied as pre-existing
No clear and unmistakable evidence that condition existed prior to service

whatConstituesCUE.description: Reducing a rating without following applicable legal safeguards under 38 CFR 3.344.
examples: Reducing a rating that had been in effect for 5+ years without showing sustained improvement
Single examination used to reduce a rating without considering overall disability picture

whatConstituesCUE.type: Failure to apply benefit of the doubt
whatConstituesCUE.description: When evidence is in approximate balance, the benefit of the doubt goes to the veteran (38 CFR 3.102). Failure to apply this is CUE.
examples: Evidence roughly equal for and against, but VA denied without applying reasonable doubt doctrine
Two equally competent medical opinions but VA sided with the negative without explanation

whatConstituesCUE.description: VA failed to liberally construe the veteran's filings to determine all potential claims raised by the evidence.
examples: Veteran's filing clearly raised a secondary condition but VA only addressed the primary
Evidence supported TDIU but VA did not consider it despite being reasonably raised

whatIsNOTCue.type: Disagreement with how evidence was weighed
whatIsNOTCue.description: A difference in how the evidence was evaluated is NOT CUE. You cannot reweigh the evidence under a CUE claim.
A new medical diagnosis that 'corrects' an earlier diagnosis considered in the decision is NOT CUE.
VA's failure to fulfill the duty to assist (e.g., not obtaining records, not scheduling C&P exam) is NOT CUE. However, it may be grounds for a separate appeal.
The otherwise correct application of a statute or regulation where, subsequent to the decision, there has been a change in interpretation is NOT CUE.

whatIsNOTCue.type: Evidence not in the file at the time
whatIsNOTCue.description: CUE is based solely on the evidence of record at the time of the decision. New evidence cannot form the basis of a CUE claim.

effectiveDate.rule: If CUE is granted, the decision is reversed or revised and the effective date is the date of the ORIGINAL claim — not the date the CUE was filed.
effectiveDate.significance: This is the primary power of CUE claims. A successful CUE motion can result in decades of retroactive benefits dating back to the original claim date.

requiredContent: Name of the requesting party (if different from claimant)
Date of the decision being challenged
Specific issue(s) to which the request pertains
Clear and specific description of the alleged CUE(s) of fact or law
Legal or factual basis for the allegation
Explanation of why the result would have been manifestly different
filingRequirements.noTimeLimit: CUE can be alleged at any time after a decision becomes final. There is no statute of limitations.

commonPatterns.description: Frequently observed CUE patterns identified from BVA decisions and veterans law practice

patterns.name: Wrong Diagnostic Code Applied
patterns.description: Condition rated under a diagnostic code that does not correspond to the actual diagnosed condition, resulting in lower rating.
patterns.lookFor: Compare the diagnosed condition with the DC used in the rating decision. Check if a more favorable DC was available and applicable.

patterns.name: Service Treatment Records Ignored
patterns.description: STRs in the file clearly documented an in-service event, injury, or treatment, but the rating decision failed to acknowledge or discuss them.
patterns.lookFor: Cross-reference STRs with the rating decision. If STRs show treatment for the claimed condition and the decision says 'no evidence of in-service occurrence,' this is potentially CUE.

patterns.name: Wrong Rating Criteria Applied
patterns.description: VA applied rating criteria from the wrong time period (criteria change periodically) or applied the wrong subsection of the criteria.
patterns.lookFor: Verify which version of the rating criteria was in effect at the time of the decision. Compare the criteria cited in the decision with the criteria that should have been applied.

patterns.name: Secondary Conditions Not Considered
patterns.description: Evidence in the file reasonably raised secondary service connection or secondary conditions, but VA failed to adjudicate them.
patterns.lookFor: Review medical evidence for conditions caused or aggravated by already service-connected disabilities. Check if the decision addressed all conditions raised by the evidence.

patterns.name: Benefit of Doubt Not Applied
patterns.description: Evidence was approximately balanced (in equipoise) but VA denied without applying the reasonable doubt doctrine (38 USC 5107(b), 38 CFR 3.102).
patterns.lookFor: When there is both positive and negative evidence of roughly equal weight, the veteran should prevail. Check if the decision acknowledged and applied this standard.

patterns.name: Presumptive Service Connection Ignored
patterns.description: Condition qualified for presumptive service connection (e.g., chronic disease manifesting within 1 year, Agent Orange presumptives, Gulf War presumptives) but VA did not consider or apply the presumption.
patterns.lookFor: Check if the condition appears on any presumptive lists. Verify if the veteran's service period/location qualifies. Check if the decision addressed presumptive service connection.

patterns.name: TDIU Not Considered When Reasonably Raised
patterns.description: Evidence in the file showed the veteran was unable to work due to service-connected disabilities, but VA did not consider entitlement to TDIU.
patterns.lookFor: Look for evidence of unemployability — termination letters, SSA disability awards, medical opinions on employability, veteran's own statements about inability to work.
